I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The Government of the People’s Republic of China (PRC) has requested the Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) for technical assistance (TA) for promoting a more inclusive and 
effective  disaster  risk  management  system.  The  Fact-Finding  Mission  visited  the  PRC  in 
November  2008  to  discuss  and  reach  an  understanding  with  the  Government  on  the  TA 
objectives,  scope,  terms  of  reference,  cost  estimates,  financing  plan,  and  implementation 
arrangements. The TA is included in ADB’s 2008 country program for the PRC.1 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  The PRC, with a population of 1.3 billion and a vast expanse of territory, has complex 
climatic  and  geological  conditions,  which  make  it  prone  to  diverse  disasters  and  natural 
calamities  such  as  typhoons,  earthquakes,  floods,  snowstorms,  sandstorms,  landslides, 
desertification, and drought. The country has been roiled by 50 earthquakes with intensity of 
over 7.0 on the Richter scale in the last 50 years, four of these with intensity of over 8.0. The 
number  of  major  disasters  and  natural  calamities  has  surged  in  recent  years,  causing 
substantial losses both to the people and to the economy. Each year from 1978 to 2007, on 
average, more than 7 million people have been dislocated, 45.78 million hectares of crop area 
have been affected, nearly 3 million houses have collapsed, and the economy has suffered a 
direct loss of over CNY170 billion. The rapid economic growth of the country has made the 
impact  of  these  disasters  more  significant.  The  average  annual  losses  due  to  disasters 
increased to CNY203.4 billion in 2000–2007 from CNY172.4 billion in the 1990s.  
 
3.  More recently, the Wenchuan earthquake in Sichuan province affected 10 provinces and 
municipalities, and caused major loss of life and property. A total of 69,226 people died, 17,923 
were reported missing, and about 1.5 million were evacuated. About 46 million people in all 
were affected, 8 million homes were destroyed, and 24.5 million homes were damaged. All 
services,  including  communications  (highways,  aviation,  and  railways),  telecommunication 
services, water supply, electricity and power supply, and irrigation, were disrupted. Industry was 
seriously affected and many schools and educational institutes were extensively damaged. The 
local economy was badly hit and the damage was extensive and covered all aspects of human 
life. The poor and vulnerable were affected the most. 
 
4.  The  Government  responded  rapidly  and  with  openness  to  the  disaster  and  took 
proactive steps at the highest level to mitigate it. The State Disaster Relief Commission initiated 
a level 1 emergency contingency plan. Such a plan covers the most serious class of natural 
disasters. The Prime Minister himself directed the relief operations in the Sichuan province in 
the first few days. Emergency medical teams, relief teams, fire rescue teams, the army, and the 
police  force  were  engaged  in  the  initial  rescue  and  relief  operation,  which  spread  across 
58 counties and cities. The Government is still undertaking reconstruction.  
 
5.  As demonstrated in the Wenchuan earthquake, the central Government holds the central 
and most important role in disaster risk management. It has an established system for dealing 
with emergencies and provides almost all the support. The role of the provincial and local 
governments, and of other stakeholders like private sector and civil society, is not so well 
defined,  and  they  look  to  the central  Government  to  manage  disasters.  In  the Wenchuan 
earthquake, the local public, civil society, nongovernment organizations (NGOs), the private 
sector, business enterprises, and the international community begged to assist in the immediate 
                                                 
1  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 13 November 2008.

2 
relief and restoration work. However, without a proper mechanism for social contribution to 
natural disaster relief, these efforts were largely localized and uncoordinated. The disaster risk 
management system in the PRC does not provide for coordination of relief efforts with other 
stakeholders and agencies that are eager to contribute. 
 
6.  Also, the system of public participation in disaster risk management is not developed 
and in particular does not have the legal basis it has in many developed countries or the 
normative basis in many other developing countries. The legal basis is important for individuals, 
business enterprises, both domestic and foreign, and other stakeholders to participate. This 
facilitates greater participation from the private sector, encourages public-private partnerships, 
and reduces the burden on the Government. The disaster risk management system in the PRC 
also does not have an institutional mechanism for coordinating relief work and contributions 
from the private sector and other stakeholders. Such an institutional mechanism would pinpoint 
responsibility and accountability and thereby make disaster risk management more efficient and 
effective. Another related aspect is the availability of personnel with the required skills for 
disaster risk management. Disaster risk management has few specialists in the PRC, and not a 
single  university  or  reputable  educational  institute  offers  it  as  a  discipline  of  study.  Basic 
knowledge of disaster and accident management is generally lacking and there is no training or 
capacity building at the local and grassroots level. Building capacity at the grassroots level to 
handle  disasters  and  provide  immediate  support  is  one  of  the  most  important  aspects  of 
managing disasters more efficiently. 
 
7.  The PRC Government believes it has much to learn from other countries when it comes 
to  involving  civil  society,  the  private  sector,  NGOs,  business  enterprises,  and  other  social 
groups in disaster risk management. It has therefore sought ADB’s assistance in (i) reviewing 
the  current  disaster  risk  management  system  in  the  PRC;  (ii) studying  the  disaster  risk 
management systems in developed countries, particularly with respect to the participation of 
stakeholders like the private sector, civil society, business enterprises, and NGOs, and learning 
from the best international experiences; (iii) preparing a strategy for disaster risk management 
that will facilitate greater involvement of the society and the private sector and can be adopted 
by the PRC; and (iv) pilot-testing some initiatives that could demonstrate a more inclusive and 
participatory approach to disaster risk management.  
 
8.  ADB  has  been  a  development  partner  of  the  PRC  since  1986,  and  has  provided 
substantial support for the development of its poor central and western regions. A $1 million TA 
for the Wenchuan (Sichuan) earthquake2 is supporting (i) a review of how Sichuan province 
responded to the earthquake within the existing disaster management framework; and (ii) a 
preliminary assessment of damage to, and need for, physical and social infrastructure, based on 
the Government’s own assessment, which could be a focus of ADB’s subsequent restoration 
programs or projects. ADB provided two policy notes to the PRC Government on (i) post 
disaster  rehabilitation  and  reconstruction  and  (ii)  key  issues  for  developing  earthquake 
insurance in the PRC. These notes provided key lessons from the international experiences and 
made recommendations for possible adoption by the PRC Government. 
 
 
 
 
 
                                                 
2  ADB. 2008. Technical Assistance to the People’s Republic of China for Providing an Emergency Response to 
Sichuan Earthquake. Manila (TA 7081-PRC, approved on 26 May). The TA is ongoing.

3 
II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
9.  The proposed TA is expected to lead to a more responsive, efficient, and effective 
disaster risk management system in the PRC. Its outcome will be a strategy for disaster risk 
management that is more inclusive and participatory and can be adopted by the Government.  
 
10.  The TA will support (i) a review of the current disaster risk management system in the 
PRC;3 (ii) research on and review of best international practices and experiences in disaster risk 
management  in  selected  developed  countries  with  similar  disaster-relevant  issues;  (iii)  the 
preparation of a strategy and the recommendation of actions for a more inclusive and effective 
disaster  risk  management  system,  which  the  Government  can  implement;  (iv)  a  capacity 
development program to build knowledge and capacity for disaster risk management; and 
(v) pilot-testing of a few demonstration projects that can be replicated. The study will make use 
of experience in disaster risk management in other relevant countries, and involve the active 
participation of stakeholders in the PRC. The key findings and recommendations of the final 
report will be contained in a policy note to be submitted to the State Council and senior officials 
of the PRC Government for implementation. Close collaboration and sharing of study outputs 
and lessons with other domestic and international partners will be maintained. The design and 
monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
11.  To  achieve  the  objectives  of  the  TA,  consultants  will  analyze  the  disaster  risk 
management  system  in  the  PRC  and  compare  it  with  counterpart  systems  in  developed 
countries  such  as  Japan,  New  Zealand,  and  Singapore  and  in  developing  countries  like 
Bangladesh,  India,  Indonesia,  and  Viet  Nam.  The  consultants  will  (i) review  the  working 
principles, systems, and methods of disaster risk management in each of these countries, and 
identify the comparative advantages of each system through an analysis of its strengths and 
weaknesses, including the features, performance, and experience of using the system, and in 
particular the key areas that encourage more active participation from the public, civil society, 
NGOs, business enterprises, and individuals throughout the country; (ii) prepare a disaster risk 
management strategy and recommending rules and regulations, working principles, institutional 
structure, methods, technology, and personnel and training needs for a more inclusive system 
that can be adopted in the PRC, as well as the key institutional, technical, legal, and other 
issues that must be dealt with; (iii) provide capacity-building support through international and 
domestic training and knowledge transfer to enhance skills and knowledge in preparation for 
participatory  and  effective  disaster  risk  management;  and  (iv) carry  out  pilot  projects  to 
demonstrate a more participatory, effective, and efficient disaster risk management system that 
can be replicated elsewhere in the country.  
 
12.  The  pilot  projects  may  involve  managing  disaster  risks  in  public  places,  industry, 
transportation, emergency rescue, and county emergency management system projects. At 
least two of the pilot projects would be implemented in the earthquake-affected provinces of 
Sichuan and Shaanxi. The pilot projects will test the disaster risk management in real life 
situations and include mock drills. The consultants will use the experience in other countries, 
engage the active participation of stakeholders in the PRC, implement national and international 
                                                 
3  Particularly in relation to the guidelines contained in the National Plan for Comprehensive Disaster Reduction 
during the 11th Five-Year Plan period (2006–2010), which was announced in August 2007.

4 
training programs, and recommend a set of actions to help the Government set up a more 
inclusive and effective disaster risk management system in the PRC. The recommendations 
should be realistic and capable of being implemented by the Government. 
 
13.  The TA will be undertaken in close consultation with the Government, the Promotion 
Center for Emergency Assistance (PCEA) of the Ministry of Civil Affairs, and other relevant 
agencies. Key activities will include (i) a review of available information on the disaster, from 
studies made by the Government, ADB,4 other multilateral institutions, and other agencies; 
(ii) data analysis; and (iii) consultations with other stakeholders. Workshops—one each at the 
inception, interim, and draft final report stages of TA implementation—will be organized to 
discuss and review the TA findings.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
14.  The TA is estimated to cost $840,000 equivalent. ADB will finance $650,000 with a grant 
from  its  TA  funding  program.  The  Government  will  finance  the  remainder,  equivalent  to 
$190,000,  which  will  cover  office  accommodation  and  the  counterpart  staff  required  to 
implement the TA. The detailed cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
15.  As the Executing Agency, PCEA, the nodal agency for public participation in disaster risk 
management, will supervise and monitor the TA activities, facilitate the work of the consultants, 
ensure that the PCEA benefits from their experience, and provide adequate counterpart staff 
with relevant work experience during TA implementation. The agency will set up a project 
implementation unit to oversee day-to-day implementation, coordinate with different agencies 
and  other  relevant  organizations,  and  facilitate  the  sharing  of  information  and  lessons.  A 
steering committee, also to be set up by the PCEA, will guide the consultants and discuss their 
reports at the inception, interim, and draft final report stages. Workshops will be held at these 
same stages of the TA and will be attended by representatives of PCEA, the  Ministry of 
Finance, other relevant agencies, ADB, and the consultants. A seminar will be organized after 
the final report is prepared. The final report will be published at the end of the TA.  
 
16.  A team of international consultants in association with national consultants will be hired by 
ADB through quality and cost-based selection (in a ratio of 80:20) using simplified technical 
proposal  procedures  according  to  ADB’s  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of  Consultants  (2007,  as 
amended from time to time). The TA will require about 12 person-months of international and 
about  15  person-months  of  national  consulting  services.  The  international  and  national 
consultants will have expertise in the following fields of disaster risk management: (i) concept, 
organization  and  institutional  arrangements,  design,  and  implementation;  (ii)  logistics, 
management  information  and  communication  systems,  and  technical  issues;  (iii)  legal  and 
legislative aspect; (iv) capacity building; and (v) implementation of pilot projects in disaster risk 
management. The terms of reference for the TA are in Appendix 3.  
 
17.  The  TA  will  begin  in  March  2009  and  will  be  completed  by  December  2009.  The 
consultants will be fielded in March 2009. They will work over 6 months and complete the 
disaster risk management strategy by September 2009. The pilot projects will be completed by 
December 2009. PCEA will provide the consultants with the documents and materials they need 
                                                 
4  Including the outputs of ADB. 2008. Technical Assistance to the People’s Republic of China for Providing an 
Emergency Response to Sichuan Earthquake. Manila (TA 7081-PRC, approved on 26 May).

5 
to carry out the TA. Limited office equipment funded under the TA will be procured by the 
consultants according to ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2007, as amended from time to time), 
and will be transferred to the Government after the TA. The TA funds will be disbursed in line 
with the Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2008, as amended from time to time). 
The consultants will keep in close contact with the Executing Agency and will inform the agency 
of the progress of their work and findings.  
 
III.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
 
18.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $650,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of the People’s Republic of China for Promoting a More Inclusive and Effective 
Disaster Risk Management System, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

8  Appendix 3 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Scope of Services 
 
1.  The proposed technical assistance (TA) to the People’s Republic of China (PRC) for 
promoting a more inclusive and effective disaster risk management system will help prepare a 
more responsive and efficient disaster risk management system in the PRC. The TA will support 
(i) a review of the current disaster risk management system in the PRC; (ii) research on and 
review of best international practices and experiences in disaster risk management in selected 
countries with similar disaster-relevant issues, and the identification of key areas that facilitate 
more active participation from the public, civil society, nongovernment organizations (NGOs), 
business enterprises, and individuals throughout the country; (iii) the preparation of a strategy 
and the recommendation of actions for a more inclusive and effective disaster risk management 
system, which the Government can implement; (iv) a capacity development program to build 
knowledge  and  capacity  for  disaster  risk  management;  and  (v) pilot–testing  of  a  few 
demonstration  projects  that  can  be  replicated.  These  pilot  projects  may  include  managing 
disaster  risks  in  public  places,  industry,  transportation,  emergency  rescue,  and  county 
emergency  management  system  projects.  The  pilot  projects  will  test  the  disaster  risk 
management in real life situations and include mock drills. At least two of the pilot projects 
would be implemented in the earthquake-affected provinces of Sichuan and Shaanxi.  
 
2.  The study would make use of experience in disaster risk management in other countries, 
developed as well as developing, and involve the active participation of stakeholders in the 
PRC. The key findings and recommendations of the final report in the form of a policy note will 
be provided to the State Council and senior levels of the PRC Government for implementation. 
Close  collaboration  and  sharing  of  study  outputs  and  lessons  with  other  domestic  and 
international partners will be maintained.  
 
B.  Terms of Reference 
 
3.  The TA will involve tasks that will include those mentioned in the following paragraphs 
but will not necessarily be limited to them. 
 
4.  Disaster  Risk  Management  Specialist  (one  international  consultant  for 
5 person-months,  and  one  national  consultant  for  4 person-months).  The  consultants  will 
(i) make a comprehensive review of the disaster risk management system in the PRC, and 
analyze and compare it with the disaster risk management systems in developed countries like 
Japan,  New  Zealand,  and  Singapore;  and  in  developing  countries  like  Bangladesh,  India, 
Indonesia, and Viet Nam; and (ii) review the working principles, systems, and methods of 
disaster risk management in each of these countries, identify the comparative advantages of 
each system by analyzing its strengths and weaknesses, including the features, performance, 
and experience of using the system, and on the basis of this review recommend a system that 
can  be  adopted  in  the  PRC.  The  review  will  look  into  preparedness,  management  team 
organization  and  responsibilities,  logistics,  communications,  specific  emergency  response 
procedures, and recovery, restoration, and mitigation measures for disasters, emergencies, and 
crises. It will examine the role of other stakeholders, such as the private sector, NGOs, civil 
society, individuals, and business enterprises, in disaster risk management.  
 
5.  The recommendations will explain the method, basis, process, and models of a more 
participatory and effective disaster risk management system that can be adopted, taking into 
account technological advances, geographic conditions and other operating parameters, and

Appendix 3  9 
other factors. Suggestions will be made regarding the principles, methods, and institutional 
structure  for  disaster  risk  management,  and  the  staffing  and  training  needs  of  the  local, 
provincial, and national governments for managing and responding to disasters or emergencies 
under varying situations, fully exploiting the role of other stakeholders such as the private 
sector, NGOs, individuals, and other business enterprises.  
 
6.  The international disaster risk management specialist, as the team leader, together with 
the logistics, network communication, and pilot project development specialist, and the legal and 
institutional specialist, will prepare a strategy with recommended rules and regulations, working 
principles, institutional structure, methods, technology, and personnel and training needs for a 
system that can be adopted by the Government for the PRC. The team leader will also prepare 
the policy note and help the Promotion Center for Emergency Assistance (PCEA) of the Ministry 
of Civil Affairs in designing three to four pilot projects to demonstrate more participatory and 
effective disaster risk management. These projects may involve managing disaster risks in 
public places, industry, transportation, emergency rescue, and county emergency management 
system  projects;  at  least  two  will  be  implemented  in  the  earthquake-affected  provinces  of 
Sichuan and Shaanxi.  
 
7.  Logistics, Network Communication, and Pilot Project Development Specialist (one 
international consultant for 4 person-months, and 2 national consultants for 4 person-months 
each).  The  consultants  will  (i)  examine  the  logistics  and  the  network  communication  and 
information system for disaster risk management in the PRC, and analyze and compare them 
with those of similar systems in developed counties like Japan, New Zealand, and Singapore; 
and in developing countries like Bangladesh, India, Indonesia, and Viet Nam; and (ii) review the 
working  principles,  the  logistic  system  and  methods,  and  the  network  communication  and 
information  system  for  disaster  risk  management  in  each  of  these  countries,  identify  the 
comparative advantages of each system through an analysis of strengths and weaknesses, 
including the features, performance, and experience of using the system, and, on the basis of 
this review, recommend a system that can be adopted in the PRC.  
 
8.  The recommendations will explain the principles, method, process, and models that can 
be adopted, taking into account issues like transportation capacity, logistic capability, response 
time,  capacity  of  the  network  communication  and  information  system,  compatibility  with 
technical  standards,  interface  with  existing  technologies  and  technical  standards,  and 
compatibility with PRC communication and information system standards and other operating 
parameters. Suggestions will be made regarding the principles, methods, institutional structure, 
and staffing and training needs for managing and responding to disasters, emergencies, and 
crises  under  varying  situations  throughout  the  PRC.  Special  emphasis  will  be  given  to 
examining how the civil society, the private sector, individuals, and other stakeholders can be 
involved in order to have a more participatory and effective disaster risk management system 
and  reduce  the  burden  of  disaster  mitigation  on  the  Government.  The  consultants  will 
recommend the management team organization and responsibilities for prevention, emergency 
response, recovery, and mitigation measures to be adopted in disasters, emergencies, and 
crises.  
 
9.  The logistics, network communication, and pilot project development specialist, with the 
team leader, will assist PCEA in designing and implementing three to four pilot projects for 
demonstration.  
 
10.  Legal and Institutional Specialist (one international and one national consultant, for 
3 person-months each). The consultants will (i) review the rules, regulations, and institutional

10  Appendix 3 
structure  for  disaster  risk  management  in  the  PRC,  and  analyze  and  compare  these  with 
counterpart systems in developed counties like Japan, New Zealand, and Singapore; and in 
developing  countries  like  Bangladesh,  India,  Indonesia,  and  Viet  Nam;  and  (ii)  review  the 
efficacy of the rules, regulations, and institutional structure in each country, and identify the 
comparative advantages of each system by analyzing its strengths and weaknesses, including 
the features, performance, and experience of using the system and the institutional setup for 
efficient and effective disaster risk management in each of the countries. On the basis of the 
foregoing review, the consultants will recommend (i) rules and regulations; (ii) an institutional 
structure;  and  (iii)  more  active  and  effective  participation  from  the  private  sector,  NGOs, 
individuals,  business  enterprises,  civil  society,  and  other  stakeholders  in  disaster  risk 
management in the PRC. 
 
11.  The recommendations should be consistent and compatible with national rules and 
regulations  in  the  PRC  for  disaster  risk  management,  should  clearly  explain  how  the 
recommendations can be integrated with those rules and regulations, and should encourage the 
opening up of the disaster risk management system to more active participation in investment 
and management from the private sector and civil society. The recommendations would also 
include suggested methods and staffing and training needs for the integration of the disaster 
risk  management  system  to  enable  effective  management  and  response  to  disasters, 
emergencies, and crises under varying situations throughout the PRC. 
 
12.  Capacity Development and Information Dissemination Component. The consultants 
will provide capacity-building support through international and domestic training and knowledge 
transfer in each of the three foregoing areas. Under the international training program 12–15 
officials from relevant departments of the PCEA will make a 15-day visit to another country or 
countries  like  Japan,  New  Zealand,  and  Singapore  to  learn  from  the  best  international 
experiences.  The  consultants  will  also  organize  domestic  training  programs,  in  close 
coordination with the PCEA, to explain the study concepts, the study research report, and the 
possible recommendations for the PRC. The content of the training and the list of participants 
will have to be approved beforehand by ADB. 
 
13.  The consultants and the PCEA will organize an information dissemination campaign to 
share the lessons and the good practices, and may use information brochures, books, and other 
reading and publicity materials for this purpose. The lessons and experience from the pilot 
projects will be shared. 
 
14.  The consultants will also organize workshops at the inception, interim, and draft final 
report stages of the TA to discuss the findings and the outputs, and a seminar after the final 
report is submitted to disseminate the findings and outcome of the TA. 
 
C.  Reporting Requirements  
 
15.  The consultants will submit the following reports: (i) an inception report 2 weeks after the 
start of the services, (ii) an interim report by the end of the 12th week, (iii) a draft final report by 
the end of the 20th week, and (iv) a final report (with around five pages of key findings and 
recommendations) after the 6th month. The PCEA requires five copies of each report in English 
and Chinese, while the Ministry of Finance (TA Division) needs two copies of each report in 
English and Chinese. ADB requires five copies of each report in English. The final report 
(bilingual) will be edited for publication. All reports will be submitted in both hard and soft copy.
